title: Lots of questions but not many answers: ALP joins press freedom fight
text:
Pressed about the issue in question time on Tuesday, Mr Morrison said the only basis people should be prosecuted on is if they have broken the law.

“The ALP is asking us to rule out consent even before any advice is received from any of the relevant agencies, which would be unprecedented and most likely unlawful,” Mr Morrison said.

But in his letter to MPs on behalf of the media coalition, News Corporation executive Campbell Reid said Australians did indeed live in a country where politicians could decide who was hauled before the courts, and that needed to change.

"The reason we are in this situation is that government has passed laws that have made the ordinary work of journalists to keep the public informed a crime," the letter said.

"Like the Prime Minister, we do not believe an individual politician should be placed in the dangerous position of being the final arbiter on whether or not a person should be prosecuted.

"We believe that laws that put a politician in this compromising position should be amended so this situation does not arise.

"We are not seeking anything like the 'blanket exemption' that some have claimed. We are asking for common sense changes to laws so that, like politicians, the unique role journalists have in serving society is acknowledged."

Advertisement

Senate estimates deflections

While media companies lobby for the overhaul of press freedom rules, opposition and minor party MPs repeatedly found their lines of questioning at Senate estimates hearings shut down.

To avoid being interrogated too deeply or address politically sensitive issues, ministers and bureaucrats often deflected by taking questions on notice, giving officials weeks to massage their response.

Mr Morrison's own department of Prime Minister and Cabinet took 125 questions on notice on Monday alone.

Labor leader Anthony Albanese told Tuesday's caucus meeting the Opposition needed to link the Your Right to Know campaign with the fact Mr Morrison "refuses to give a straight answer to a simple question".

In one notable exchange, bureaucrats cited harm to international relations for their refusal to answer whether Mr Morrison's office had put forward Hillsong church pastor Brian Houston to be included on the guest list for a state dinner at the White House last month. Mr Morrison has dismissed questions over the issue as "gossip".
description: Media industry says the PM's admission he would not want to live in a country where politicians decide prosecutions proves their point about the need for law changes.
